Award.AwardTitle: US Trainee Travel Awards to attend the 2nd Timing Research Forum: Queretaro, Mexico - October 2019

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Time perception is a critical feature of behavior, affecting all levels of perception, action, and cognition. However, timing in the perceptual and cognitive sciences has historically been understudied. Understanding how this important facet of everyday life is accomplished requires a multidisciplinary approach across multiple domains. The Timing Research Forum conferences are designed to fill this need.

This award provides support for US graduate students and postdoctoral trainees to travel to and attend the 2019 Timing Research Forum, October 15-18, 2019. One unique feature of the forum will be a 'Timing Moonshot' discussion, in which field leaders and conference participants will define the major problems and research agendas for the next five years.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Time perception is a critical feature of behavior, impacting all levels of perception and cognition, across most mobile organisms. This award supported the attendance of nineteen, diverse graduate and postdoctoral trainees to attend the premiere multidisciplinary international conference in this topic, the Timing Research Forum (TRF). The TRF conference is a multi-day event that fills a unique need in bringing a wide range of disparate disciplines that study time perception into contact. Through their participation, it provided is a unique opportunity to expose trainees to the full breadth of the field of timing research, introducing them to new approaches, ideas and future collaborators and mentors. The outcomes of the conference included the abovementioned educational opportunities, dissemination of trainee research and sharing of conference insights with their home lab group, and the development of stronger national research capacity in a diverse group of young scientists with the potential to address the importance of timing in the every-day activities of all humans. Testimonials from the trainees supported by this award strongly attest that the participation enabled by this grant accomplished all of these objectives and would have a lasting impact on the quality of their research as well as their future career.
